title: Kotlin Class
content: Kotlin supports both functional and object-oriented programming.

Before you create objects in Kotlin, you need to define a class. We can think of class as a sketch (prototype) of a house. It contains all the details about the floors, doors, windows etc. Based on these descriptions we build the house. House is the object.
To define a class in Kotlin, class keyword is used:

title: Kotlin Objects
content: When class is defined, only the specification for the object is defined; no memory or storage is allocated.
To access members defined within the class, you need to create objects. Let's create objects of Lamp class.
code: val l1 = Lamp() // create l1 object of Lamp class
val l2 = Lamp() // create l2 object of Lamp class
